channel.title: Conference on Alex Bachuk
channel.description: Recent content in Conference on Alex Bachuk

item.title: Fluent 2014 Conference review
item.description: The Fluent conference was great. San Francisco, sunny weather, good food, awesome speakers, a lot of new content. A lot of sessions was about performance and angular.js. I was expecting more discussions around Node.js, but I guess this is front end conference. [caption id=“attachment_711” align=“aligncenter” width=“700”]Inventor of JavaScript Brandon Eich, keynote. [/caption] Angular.js clearly has won JavaScript MVC battle. Last year (different conference though) I saw a lot more sessions on Backbone.

item.title: Fluent 2014 conference day 1
item.description: Fluent is annual conference in San Francisco mostly about JavaScript. It’s my first time to this conference and San Francisco. The conference started with day of workshops, I attended workshops on automating all things front-end, web RTC and Angular.js fundamentals. To be honest, I was expecting more hands-on practice, but I still was able to learn something new. Front end workflow automation is all about grunt tasks and plugins. I was familiar with some of the tools mentioned here, like livereload, which is huge time saver while working locally, it compiles sass, less, haml, and other on the fly and updates web page automatically without reloading, definitely a must have for any developer.

item.title: jQueryTO in Toronto Canada.
item.description: This was my first web development conference that’s not WordCamp. I started developing with JavaScript quite recently, before that I was using jQuery to manipulate DOM and use others plugins (which works for small websites pretty well). Since it was not that far from New York City - I decided to attend and see what’s new in jQuery world (especially after I saw Paul Irish and Addy Osmani among other speakers).
